Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Large: Collaborative Research: HyperFlow - A Hybrid IP/Optical Flow Network Architecture

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will create and demonstrate experimentally key features of a new optical network architecture, 'HyperFlow' which is a hybrid future Internet architecture that include key designs for both hardware and algorithms. The network is designed to be dynamic (both agile and adaptive), and significantly more cost effective and power efficient for future growth in data volumes and number of users. The architecture relies on a novel optical network infrastructure comprising new transport mechanisms and a new comprehensive control mechanism including the physical hardware, algorithms and applications.

Between locations that exchange large volumes of data - say, Los Angeles and New York City ? the flow switching mechanism of HyperFlow would establish a dedicated path across the network. The allotment of bandwidth would change constantly. As traffic between New York and Los Angeles increased, new, dedicated wavelengths would be recruited to handle it; as the traffic tailed off, the wavelengths would be relinquished. The goal is to develop network management protocols that can perform new session allocations in a matter of sub-seconds. HyperFlow can easily increase the data rates of optical networks 100-fold with the new network management scheme to be addressed in this program, with corresponding decrease in cost per bit and power consumption as well.

Intellectual Merit: HyperFlow creates a complete hybrid flow/IP network architecture spanning local to wide areas, sharing the same unified control plane. The network provides both guaranteed end-to-end multi-Gbps flow service and conventional Internet Packet services throughout the network down to individual users. To achieve that goal, HyperFlow includes novel access and long haul core network technologies designed to support end-to-end flows as well as conventional IP network services. This approach achieves a breakthrough with respect to previous approaches by providing both services end-to-end with a unified control plane. HyperFlow includes major innovations based on highly efficient, agile and control of pools of shared tunable lasers and passive optical devices, a fast MAC, partitioned routing strategy and a new transport protocol for flows.

Broader impact: If successful the proposed HyperFlow technology will have a profound influence on the way the future Internet is designed and perceived by the society, as the new on-demand cost-effective gigabit service will enable applications that are hard or costly to support today with existing broadband access, such as instantly-available 3D distributed virtual-reality systems, cloud computing and instant file transfer services including telemedicine, education, 3D movies, concerts, sporting events, and government services. The concept of the new Hyperflow development will be brought into industry forums such as IETF/IRTF during the project, so that the best minds of the industry can be leveraged for conceptual validation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The aim of this project was to create and demonstrate experimentally key features of a new optical network architecture (UltraFlow), which is a hybrid future Internet architecture that includes key designs for both hardware and algorithms. The network is designed to be dynamic (both agile and adaptive), and significantly more cost effective and power efficient for future growth in data volumes and number of users. The architecture relies on an optical network infrastructure comprising new transport mechanisms and a new comprehensive control mechanism, which accounts for the physical hardware limitations and applications requirements. Between locations that exchange large volumes of data the flow switching mechanism of UltraFlow establishes a dedicated path across the network. The allotment of bandwidth would be adjusted in real-time. UltraFlow can easily increase the data rates of optical networks 100-fold, with corresponding decrease in cost per bit and power consumption as well.

UltraFlow is a complete hybrid flow/IP network architecture spanning local to wide areas, sharing the same unified control plane. The network provides both guaranteed end-to-end multi-Gbps flow service and conventional Internet packet services throughout the network down to individual users. To achieve that goal, UltraFlow includes access and long haul core network technologies designed to support end-to-end flows as well as conventional IP network services. UltraFlow includes major innovations based on highly efficient, agile control of a pools of shared tunable lasers and passive optical devices, a fast MAC, partitioned routing strategy and a new transport protocol for data flows.

In this projects, a group of researchers at MIT, Stanford University, and the University of Texas at Dallas investigated some of these innovative architectures, quantifying their performance superiority and identifying the most promising practices for the industrial sector to pursue. The UT Dallas team focused its efforts on two network architectures with the specific objective of supporting highly dynamic and voluminous data transfer requests through the design of reconfigurable optical networks, in contrast with the static or quasi-static optical network architectures deployed today. The two network architectures comprise the conventional GMPLS control plane-based Wavelength Switched Optical Network (WSON) and the Optical Flow Switched (OFS) network. The former solution is widely available and already deployed at this time, representing a meaningful legacy solution. The latter, originally proposed by the MIT team, is still in its conceptual phase, requiring a significant redesign of the entire protocol stack all the way to the transport layer. The two architectures can coexist, as the former can be used to pre-provision quasi-static optical lightpaths between cities across the wide area network (WAN) and across the metro area network (MAN), between the distribution network points of access and the hubs (where WAN and MAN are interconnected), while the latter can be applied on top of the pre-provisioned quasi-static lightpaths to achieve real-time scheduling of optical flows.

Contributions to OFS networking include an upgraded protocol version that yields improved resource utilization in the distribution (access) network from the original 20% to a more desirable 50-60%. This resource utilization gain is achievable with a minor change in the original protocol that requires minimal increase in complexity.

Contributions to the GMPLS control plane include a technique to reduce the occurrence of resource race condition in the protocol. The study identified three types of race conditions (B-Race for bandwidth race condition, S-Race for spectrum race condition and M-Race for cross-talk margin race condition) that may occur while attempting to reserve optical circuits in GMPLS WDM networks. It then investigated the effect on network blocking by race condition type and explained how an already existing TLV in the IETF RSVP signaling may be employed to inform the destination node of a potential race condition occurrence. An informed destination can then choose the appropriate wavelength assignment algorithm that can reduce the probability of race condition by up to one order of magnitude.

Other outcomes of this project include analytical models for quantifying the unfair nature of service admission in flexible grid optical links and networks. Intuitively, services requesting a small number of spectrum slices are more likely to be admitted, when compared to services that request a large number of continuous spectrum slices. Analytical (exact and approximate) models were proposed that are able to quantify the uneven blocking probability that originates in this context. Admission strategies were proposed that can mitigate the problem without significantly affecting the overall service blocking probability.

A number of graduate and undergraduate students have been involved in this project, which provided them with research and software development/integration challenges, as well as the opportunity of being exposed to hands-on experiments in a collaborative and international research environment. Five students completed their Ph.D. degree during the project, three of which are female. These students are now working with companies like Cisco Systems, contributing to current and future products.
